comments.commentBody: The US government should not permit foreign ownership of factories producing vital military equipment, such as Dresser-Rand.

I also had a personal experience with "Obamacare". A very positive one ..
it took me about 30 minutes to signup using the CT website. My email confirmation came within 48 hours. The insurance company bill came about 2-3 weeks later ! My health insurance costs dropped quite a bit vs. the COBRA coverage I had been paying !

Most of the folks whom I know ho hate the program have
little to no experience with the plan OR are Obama haters. Now that we know millions more Americans have health care coverage we still hear of silly stories about how the program has failed. Does anyone care about facts ?

Um...ok. A link to an article stating that Indians don't care because they've been through worse and have more pressing problems.

But, they still wouldn't mind if the name got changed right? I think you are confused about the point of the article. They want their voice to be heard. It doesn't help a major representation of them is through a corporate logo with a name that demeans them. We can change the team's name and also give them a voice.

The idea that "Redskins" is insulting to native americans is received wisdom among liberal journalists like yourself. There is ample evidence suggesting that it's not at all insulting but is instead the hobby horse of a set of professional activists that sympathetic and easily outraged liberals have backed. I'm not sure how deeply you've delved into the data or research regarding how native americans feel about the term but here is an interesting article written a few months back by a writer who seemed to accept the received wisdom just like you did but who, upon doing field research, learned his initial suppositions about the word "redskins" were completely incorrect -

http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2013/nov/02/real-reason-dont-mind-redskin...

Is there anything dumber than lugging a huge heavy purse/handbag full of stuff around?

If this were a good thing men wouldn't just be designing pocketbooks with their logos on them, but would be carrying them, too--and wearing platform wedged/stiletto heeled shoes besides.

Pockets! What a great idea.

Thanks Mr. Nawi!!!
PS: Just wondering, why does the author presume that the non-white women buying Michael Kors bags are "impoversished"? And who is she to judge others about how they spend their money?

Football is offensive and hurtful to all. That is why we watch it. The name of the team reflects the game but not the political campaigns of the aggressive left. The pressure to change will ease when Obama goes.

Not the govt's responsibility, even when it's policies directly lead to joblessness and spiraling down of financial security? And govt does this to enrich the already rich, and thereby enrich the lawmakers themselves? Wake up from the rw fantasy world.

But surviving at subsistence level is not what a modern civilization should force on citizens. Aren't you aware that millions of jobs have been offshored, with little funding for training and education? For years people were deprived of medical insurance and retirement pensions? The stats show wages stagnant while the nations wealth flows up to the 1 percent? Have you been under a rock?

The jobs are simply not there for millions. It's not a question of finding some other way. Other countries have kept more jobs within their borders, and supported education and training for workers to a greater extent. See OECD statistics on greater income equality. They support unions and still manage to make profits. That's called a positive spiral, since it raises people's confidence and living standards, rather than rolling them back, with destructive effects on individuals and families. The resulting consumer demand enables profits, as our history shows.

I'm not sure I understand your point here.  Do you think it's wrong for an oppressed group to appropriate *among themselves* an insult used by mainstream society to diminish and marginalize them, while simultaneously finding the term still offensive when used by members of the privileged mainstream (i.e., whites, able-bodied people, etc.)?  Because I would respectfully disagree.  The former is a way for people operating under a genuine disadvantage to use irony as a form of empowerment.  The latter, I think, winds up still being people with privilege using oppressive language to oppress.  Because, honestly, why else would you want to call someone something that you know they will find offensive?

It is interesting how the disenfranchised group can frame the argument.  I had a boss who was a former disability activist and he explained that disabled persons could  force others to call them by their preferred name (disabled) and not "handicapped. "  But he would turn around and  and as a matter of pride call himself and other persons with disabilities "cripples" just as you hear the word "queer" used.   So it depends on who is using the "Redskins" name as to whether it is offensive.  So when Indian groups say it is offensive, then it becomes popular to denounce the use of the word "Redskins."

Well stated. I would only add that the author also assumes that the long-term use of SSRIs decreases the likelihood of suicide. There is no long-term evidence that this is the case (note his own admission to a complete lack of long-term studies), and there is significant concern that they may, in fact, increase the suicide rate even in the short term, as suicides for non-suicidal participants in drug trials had a significantly higher rate of suicidal feelings or behavior than those on placebo in a number of studies.

It is the responsibility of those providing treatment to show evidence of effectiveness and safety. The doctor admits this has not been done, and yet recommends no change in practice. Not a rational conclusion.
You are a clever clever girl, and you get Italy.

Hair restoration procedures is great technique of man especially.

I have procedure of Baldness http://www.thelondonhairclinic.co.uk/bespoke-hair-systems.html

I think that much of the research in this area confounds the 'Why we laugh?' investigation and our relationship with humor and comedy. In Provine's 'Laughter: A Scientific Investigation' there is a lot of solid work to show how intriguingly distinct these 2 areas of research really are ... humor and laughter are not somehow directly connected and, in fact, the purpose of humor is not always to produce genuine, out loud laughter as a response { think of Swift's 'Gulliver's Travels' or much of the writing of Twain ... both of which use observational humor as a meta-commentary on humanity and sociological dynamics we experience in the world }.

I do, however, believe that looking at this subject / question ... 'Why do we laugh?' ... deepens when looked at from the various perspectives involved with this very mysterious human phenomena ... and both the philosophical perspectives as well as the various vantage points of looking at things from the POV of: the laugher; the social scenario and context of the laugh event; the humorist; comedic performers; participants in social laugh situations; as well as peripheral non-participants { sometimes even 'targets' } of humor, laughter, etcetera.

I still think we haven't clearly defined the formal landscape for looking at laughter in a more scientific way, although all basic philosophical thought behind this topic is fairly well established, sort of flying around the real the answer(s) to the 'Why do we laugh?' question.

I also am a big MRS fan yet in disagreement with blanching. I tried blanching a few weeks ago mid-way through a large harvest pesto batch - being recommended by both cooks illustrated and saveur caught my attention - but the second the basil leaves touched the hot water and wilted (of course), I regretted it. Not only did I lose fresh leaf flavor and texture, now my basil quantity halved, so my other ingredients went on the shelf until the next harvest. I am truly mystified why this is so popular. But thanks for all the great recipes... This just happened to be a remarkable side note,

This article was interesting and enlightening.  I was not aware that dogs have the ability to distinguish cancer cells from regular by using their sense of smell.    Dogs are multi talented as well as great companions and I think it's a fantastic idea that scientists take advantage of their skills.  I realize that more research is needed but anyway that cancer can be detected and save a life is worth investigating. The article focused on ovarian cancer and how early detection could save a life.

It was interesting to read that airplane crew have a higher risk of developing melanoma.  The only explanation given is the possibility of greater UVA radiation exposure.  Further research and studies need to be conducted in order to determine why people working on air flights are at an increased risk for melanoma.  This can be a deadly disease and if there is a way to reduce or eliminate this health risk it should be investigated. Learning more about the causes would not only save lives but also money needed to care for melanoma patients.

I used to eat breakfast everyday until I was 14 years old.  Perhaps it's about not having enough sleep or under too much pressure, when I wake up in the morning I just don't feel like eating breakfast.  Then I noticed that lots and lots of research shows how important breakfast is to one's body.  I forced myself to eat breakfast everyday but that doesn't make me feel better and even worse.  Sometimes I even feel like I'm going to throw up.  That's when I started thinking is breakfast really that important.  So I think that I will eat breakfast on my free will, that's is definitely better to my body.
The cat picture is indeed awesome.

Orthotics for shoes and sneakers prescribed by my doc and wearing crocs when not wearing shoes, help minimize the discomfort. The crocs are great.

The cross section of comments have been very interesting. I have varying intensities of PF, Achilles tendonitis and retro calcaneal bursts, pain in my ball underneath my big toes and more. My walking range is one mile but I can play singles tennis for 90 minutes as long as I play every other day,
I will try working on the trigger points in my foot and purchasing some of the recommended food supplements,

Thanks to all
Www.sl-cpa.net

Susan, I guess you didn't get that I was commenting sarcastically - & I thought humorously - on the photo.

Your comment actually makes my point - lighten up.

Yes, addicts, like everyone else, do need pleasures and joys in life. What neither they nor anyone else needs are rigid definitions of what constitutes pleasure.

- And those people in the photo DO look grim.

When I had recurrent plantar fasciitis, I incorporated barefoot running into my running regime and never suffered from it again.  My working theory is that it went away because of better force absorption from mid/front striking and strengthening of intrinsic foot muscles.

I went to four doctors- I had inserts, shots and physical therapy- not to mention the quackadoodle stuff I bought over the internet. I was practically immobile- and had to have my groceries.

Finally I went to a great doctor- never be satisfied with yours if you get no relief. Two visits did it.

Every diagnosis is different- but mine was caused by tight calf muscles.

He said most of the physical therapists are not well trained and are a waste of time.

He had me doing simple stretching exercises, against a wall while sitting.
Also he had me wear the boot, but not overnight but for one hour each night- three on the affected foot and one night on the other. Inspected my shoes,told me to wear good quality walking shoes and low/medium heeled shoes like wedges ( not stilettos).

I went back to doing Yoga- an enormous help.
They  used to smoke a lot back then.

Amy,
I had plantar fasciitis for years in my early and mid-20's (I'm now 32), and the way I finally worked it out was with a lacrosse ball. I roll the bottom of my foot over it, pressing hard into it, much like one would use a foam roller to loosen muscles and break up lactic acid. It only takes 30 seconds or so per day, and I just have the lacrosse ball on the floor ready to go use at any time. Later, after an unrelated ankle injury, I had a physical therapist who agreed the lacrosse ball was the best way to work out plantar fasciitis. I have had one other friend who has used the same method, a distance runner, and it has worked for her. I no longer have bad plantar fasciitis, and I still use the lacrosse ball every day. I hope this helps!
This happened to me, too! both the heel and my calf were in pain. I'm not doing it any more!

Amy, I've been doing this exercise as the article suggested per the direction of my podiatrist for a week or so.  I have only done it 4 times since it’s an every other day exercise. Yes it was excruciatingly painful, but it hurt in all the right places.  The other stretching exercises I've been given over the past 5 painful months didn't hurt at all!  The first day, it was like someone was stabbing/slashing my foot with knives.  What was worse though was when my calf was all knotted up and practically seized up on me the next day.  I realized I should have stretched my calf out really well before and after!  By the time I did the exercise 2 days later, I was stretching my calf out really well, no more calf problems and the 2nd time, It really hurt, but not as much. After the 2nd exercise session, my pain started subsiding, finally getting better after 5 months!   My doc has me in a boot right now as well, so I am not putting any pressure on the plantar fascia at all. I was in a boot for 3 weeks before this and while that felt slightly improved, as soon as I tried not wearing the boot, I was in the same amount of pain as before. (It felt like I stepped on a nail and the nail was still in the heel of my foot.) After 4 of these exercise sessions, when I press on my heel now, I barely feel any pain.  Fingers crossed when I get out of the boot in 2 more weeks, it’s all gone!

This excecise hurt the bad heel terribly, and I was in a lot of pain for the next 24 hours! I'm afraid to try it again. If I do it with both feet simultaneously it stretches things out and feels good, but as shown is was excrutiating.
I've had Plantar Fasciitis pain for over a year now. I've gone to a good physical therapist, and done many exercises, have orthotics, etc. I can feel better for a short time, but as soon as I do any substantial walking the pain returns. In desperation I'm trying accupuncture now.
Why no Crocs in the shower? I have a pair that stays clean- I just use them to go between locker room and pool, and also travel with them to get better traction in hotel showers.

I had terrible stabbing pains in my heels and thought hobbling around in the morning was just part of getting old.  I looked it up online and realized it was probably plantar fasciitis.  I read online nursing forums and discovered they had problems from standing on tile floors for extended hours, and the consensus seemed to be to wear Crocs every waking hour unless in the shower.  I wore regular cushioned shoes to work and every moment I was not wearing career wear shoes I wore Crocs.  The nurses were right!  It took me about a year, and I don't wear heels or thin soled shoes, but I don't suffer from any type of foot pain at all any more.

My 2 cents on all running injuries:

#1 cause: being too heavy. And I mean barely too heavy. Running is a brutal activity, and for every bit that you are above 2 lbs/inch of height (which is most of us) you are increasing your chance of getting hurt.

#2) going too far or too fast, too soon.

#3) running on concrete.

Other than that, I think stretching and specific exercises are rather superfluous. That's my experience after 20+ years of running. My worst knee injuries came from being slightly overweight (and I mean..slightly). My worst foot injuries from speed work. IT band syndrome--too far, too soon, on hard surfaces.
